name: Turnbow
comment info:
Title: Back 2 Africa. 
The title is a play on the fact that most of the high-fertility nations are in Africa and have been for some time.

The largest determining factor for high fertility rates is economic growth and development.
When we were mainly an agriculturally-based society, farming required a lot more physical labor and hands to do this on each farm.  As we became Industrialized, families needed less kids. And now, as a Technologically-driven economy, kids have become more of a cost and financial burden; just ask the South Koreans (they have the lowest fertility rate in the world).

Most of the 1st World Nations have been undergoing fertility crises for some time, including the U.S, Britain, China, Russia, Japan, Korea, and Germany, and France.
And this crises was intensified by the widespread development of the birth control pill.
What has kept depopulation at bay for a number of developed nations, including the U.S (my home), Germany, England, and France, has been immigration.
In the U.S, we’ve used immigrants as a cheap source of labor, but also as a source investment.

But most importantly, we’ve used them for growth. You see, if we don’t maintain the replacement rate, our economic growth, our retirement system, our labor force, our education system, our retail markets, and a lot of other parts of our product-driven economy will all start to fall apart rather quickly.

name: Colin
comment info: The two major influencing factors are ommitted from the article, and why would be an interesting topic for investigation. Education and religion. Many research programs have clearly proven that there is a direct correlation between a woman's IQ and the number of children she will have - the higher her IQ the fewer children she will have.  Countries by IQ will show an almost parallel graph. And the stronger a country is influenced by religion, the more children will be born. Stating facts is not racial. It is essential if we  genuinely want to understand what is happening and why.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Colin These factors are rarely discussed, unfortunately. Its akin to looking at the housing crisis and not considering immigration as a major contributing factor. These factors exist and I agree, it's absolutely far from racial and needs to be considered if we're to understand what's happening at all and how we can work together for a solution.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info:
@Paulina Azano Hester 
I think it is interesting how you pointed out that near half/close to half of women and men are less inclined to have children, and I wonder why that is. I wonder if this number will go up or down, depending on current adult generations.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Paulina Azano Hester Developing countries have higher fertility rates because children are desirable for labour (to help family operations to sustain livelihoods). Another contributing factor is the child mortality rate—developing countries have higher mortality rates and as such will have more children to compensate for potential losses. A third contributing factor is religion. Developing countries tend to be more religious than those of the first world technology-driven nations. Religion can lead people to apply extra meaning to having children.

name: Jake Heiss
comment info:
What Will Countries Do About Low Fertility Rates?

Looking at the graph, I notice that many countries have birth rates below the replacement fertility. These countries are generally very developed countries such as South Korea, Japan, Germany, and even the United States. The countries with higher fertility rates are less developed countries, typically in Africa. Low population levels can cause massive issues in the economies of countries and the workforce. This makes me wonder, what are countries doing to help stop this issues? Is this a problem that can be completely prevented? This relates to me because the declining population influences the policies governments put into place. Support systems for the elderly such as social security will not exist for much longer because the increasing burden it is putting on young people.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info:
@Jake Heiss 
Hey Jake.
Some countries are trying to counter this depopulation crisis. China for example, got rid of their one child policy and now allow families to birth more than one child. But the families no longer want to do so because it’s costly.
South Korea is trying to give women more paid leave for their pregnancies like many countries do in Europe.
And some countries, like the US, Germany, France, Spain, Italy, Russia, and England let in more immigrants to supplement the fertility loss.

name: Aubrie Rogers Block 1
comment info:
Does Infertility Help or Hurt Our Countries?

As I look at this graph, I notice a significant change in the fertility rates between different countries. As of today, fertility rates are rather low in areas like Hong Kong, China, Italy, and India (places below the replacement fertility line). However, the graph shows that in areas like Nigeria, Mali, and Niger the fertility rates are much larger. In the United States (a fertility rate of 1.7) and many other countries, there is an outstanding number of people. These places are continuously becoming overpopulated, so I find the low fertility rates in this graph quite surprising. 

The surprisingly low fertility rates makes me wonder what is causing them to become so low in the United States and some of the other areas with low rates. Is it one’s age or lifestyle that affects one’s fertility rates? And why are other places like Africa and Mali showing higher rates? I don’t think this decreasing rate of fertility will affect the United States terribly, at least in the beginning. The United States is already so overpopulated and I feel as though it will eventually be very hard to provide everyone with the resources they need. This decreasing fertility rate may help even out the amount of people within the United States, which isn’t a bad thing. I actually think this decreasing rate could be a good thing. And who knows, these decreasing rates could take an unexpected turn and start increasing.

name: Baines Ellison
comment info: Looking at todays “what's going on in this graph” I noticed a couple things after studying and analyzing it closely. First and most obviously, I noticed the diversity in total fertility rates in different places, from 6.0 in Mali to 0.7 in Hong Kong which is a crazy difference. Second, The note about where most people live  implies that a significant portion of the global population live in countries with declining birth rates. Last but not least, the concept of replacement fertility is highlighted, with a suggested threshold of about 2.1. Countries like China(1.2), India(2.0), and Italy (1.3) have a total fertility rate below this replacement level. This implies that, on average, these countries are not having enough births to replace their existing population over the long term.

name: Anonymous
comment info:
Not Baby Boomers.

I think this is mainly a cultural “issue”.  I say that because I don’t think it really is an issue but I also because the cultural importance of family differs a lot between regions.  In America, after World War II, we know that the baby boom occurred– in which the population grew immensely.  Since then most people have been having fewer and fewer children.  Most parents I know have1-3 kids.  The cultural climate is changing in America… especially as the cost of living increases.  One thing being specifically affected by this is the cost of housing, healthcare, and childcare…which are all very important in raising a child.  Many women have to quit their jobs in order to stay home with the kids which obviously means less income for the family.

name: Blaire Croom Block 1
comment info:
Seeing the graph, I notice that the bubbles as you go down the map have smaller and smaller child per woman ratio. I’ve noticed that countries at the bottom of the map, are more developed, and the rate of children per woman goes down. For example in the US, the rate of children is 1.7 per woman, because in the United States, children don't go straight out to the workforce and, unlike undeveloped countries, teens/ adults get paid a substantially greater amount than people in other countries. Although in other countries you may be able to work as a young child, America has placed The Federal Child Labor Law in place so children under the age of 14 can't work, but kids in other countries aren't so fortunate.

As you go further up the graph, places like Somalia (6.3) and Mali (6.0), the birth to woman ratio is increasingly higher than many developed countries. But a depressing truth is why the birth rates are so high in specific countries, as a woman has more children, they grow up and start working at young ages, making money for corporations that use those kids to make more money. In those countries though, they do not have laws to protect those children or teens from being unpaid in the workforce. This causes many deaths in children in those specific countries. And with the increasing demand to move to a country where the birth rates are lower and everyone who immigrated to the United States, we might experience a population influx, causing the American population to go down.

name: Morgane S-T
comment info:
In this graph, it has become clear that each dot represents a woman in a geographical location as well as the average number of children they have. These numbers are declining. Countries in Africa such as Niger, Nigeria and Chad have a much higher fertility rate than let's say China or the United States. From what I have learned, women in African and other regions nearby begin motherhood at a younger age, allowing for them to have more children. Also, it is important to know that many African countries value having larger families, which may have started to counteract the deaths of so many young children due to the lack of necessary resources. 
            On the other side of the graph, even the countries with the most number of people are the lowest in fertility rates and I have reason to believe that it is because of overpopulation. name: Jessica AOSE
comment info:
I notice that the graph is demonstrating a decrease in fertility worldwide. In larger countries which have dense populations we observe declining fertility rates which are below the replacement fertility line. I believe that this is a result of an increase in women being part of the workforce, thereby having less of a desire and opportunity to nurture a traditional family life. However, some countries have external variables that are impacting their fertility rates, such as China who have implemented the one child policy. I’m curious if we’ll see an increase in population, since these third world countries now have the opportunity to manufacture goods for first world countries thereby contributing to GDP and enhancing the resources available to the people in that country. For example, Nike now outsources their manufacturing to Vietnam which provides more employment opportunities and an increase in revenue in the country. This is relevant to my community and I because I live in the United States and our population is declining which may affect my generation and future generations because there will be less people to contribute to society politically, socially, and economically.

- We notice that developed countries have a lot lower fertility rates compared to developing nations. We think that education and cultural factors probably contribute to this disparity. name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph exhibits population size and comparison to the total fertility rate. In the graph, it is shown that Niger has a population of 100 million and has a total fertility rate of 6.8. Niger is located in West Africa and is one of the poorest countries in the world. Therefore because of their lack of advanced technologies and good health care, they probably have a higher infant mortality rate So, if they have six kids they can assume that a few of them will die at birth if not in the first few months of their lives. In addition in less developed countries like Niger, it is more socially acceptable to have more kids. Because of their lack of education women could have kids at an earlier age therefore producing more of them. In addition, the kids can go to work at very young ages so they can help provide income for the family. On the other hand, populations like China have implemented anti-natalist policies to control overpopulation. The previous one-child policy and the current two-child policy in China, enforced by the government, have resulted in lower fertility rates. However, these fertility rates are below the replacement rate of 2.1. This could negatively affect a population because the dependency ratio would be high on older people. This could also have a negative effect on economic development because the younger population will not be able to support the older population. I wonder how China is handling this issue they are facing.
“The Future is Babies”

name: Ally Carter
comment info:
The fertility rate gets lower as countries become more developed, a saddening fact that Demographic Transition Model graphs will always show. Third-world countries like Niger(6.8), Mali(6.0), and most countries in Africa all have a need for kids because their countries aren’t developed yet and therefore kids generate money by working, valuable money that ensures parental survival. It's a logical and necessary decision on their part, it's their means of survival.
      However, other countries like the US(1.7) and Germany(1.5) are in the “Industrial” and “Post-Industrial” stages of the Demographic Transition Model, meaning that they no longer have such a need for children and now have kids because of desire rather than need. However, because their replacement rate is lower than the fertility rate in these countries, like the US, immigrants are essential to replenish the workforce and ensure continuation. When this immigration surge stops we end up with countries like Germany who pay in extreme amounts for foreign workers and try desperately to increase fertility rates. It leads one to wonder, what will happen when all countries end up in the “Post-Industrial” and 1st world stage like Germany and Japan? Will we find a way around it? Or will we go extinct?

name: Sofia - Mrs. Francois 5B AP Lang Class
comment info:
Falling Fertility - The Baby Decline:

- What do you notice?
There is an increasing number of countries with a decreasing fertility rate. Additionally, more developed countries tend to be lower on the graph (below replacement TFR), such as European & North American countries. 

- What do you wonder?
How are these countries moving up and down in accordance to population statistics?
We are also curious as the to predictive fertility rates for the next 50 years.
What are future implications of the population declining due to below replacement fertility?
What is the global total fertility rate?

- How does this relate to you and your community?
US fertility rate is below replacement value, so we will need a younger population to support an increasingly aging population in order to maintain stable economic and governmental support programs (social security, other programs funded by working populations' taxes, etc).
This also speaks towards the shifting power imbalances as a result of globalization between countries of the Global North and Global South.
Lower fertility rates could cause future problems.
This topic inherently ties into women's rights and education, as less educated women are more likely birth more children when they are younger.


As usual, thank you for the interesting prompts! :)
- Ms. Francois 5B AP Language class

name: Sherry Block 1
comment info:
First of all, this graph displays the fertility rates of the world: with Niger at the top at 6.8, it would be a major understatement to say that the amount of children born to each woman is excessive and unnecessary, though not surprising. Africa has always historically had the highest fertility rates, mostly due to a lack of access to contraceptives and education, as well as the prevalence of polygamy and adolescent marriages. 
      As this graph shows, most developed countries, including the United States, have lower fertility rates, the majority of them being under the replacement fertility threshold. It’s interesting to note that global birth rates have declined over time, which I believe is mostly due to increases in cost of living and childcare, developments in women’s rights, and urbanization, all of which are particularly high in first world countries.
      What concerns me mostly is how low fertility rates have dropped and how that might affect the population. In some places like Japan and South Korea, the birth rate is so low that schools started shutting down because they couldn’t sustain the costs of the institution. In fact, it was so bad that, at any given moment, there were only one or two children actively attending a class. I genuinely hope that those kinds of circumstances don’t spread to the United States and other developed countries, though there might not be so much hope for us either.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: For the first time in recent history, the U.S. population is projected to drop by 2080. News outlets are already covering this new discovery, exclaiming that the population depends heavily on immigration, according to the U.S. Census Bureau. What could this mean for us and our country? Well, I don’t want to find out, but we could potentially see economic consequences, such as shortages in staff and declining market demands. I fear for smaller local businesses especially, since they don’t have the resources to combat these issues. Although I also have hopes that a declining population might stabilize environmental stresses and mitigate inflation, cost of living and increase quality of life, I wouldn’t wish for it to continue in the case that it becomes catastrophic.

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph depicts the fertility rate of countries around the world; the lowest rate being Hong Kong at 0.7 and the highest being Niger at 6.8. The graph also draws a gray dotted line showing the ideal replacement fertility rate, 2.1 children per pair of parents, which would sustain the population shifting from one generation to the next. Interestingly, most major countries fall below the ideal replacement fertility rate. Some of which being the US (1.7), India (2.0), Japan (1.3), the UK (1.6), Germany (1.5), and Russia (1.5). Not so shockingly, China falls low at 1.2 children per set of parents, which was a goal of the old one-child policy. I wonder how this will end up affecting the economy and workforce. More specifically, how will manual labor jobs be affected? As people get older, it gets harder for them to efficiently perform hard physical labor. So, will businesses be negatively impacted if there is less accessibility to younger workers? In my community, small shops tend to rely on teenagers as employees. In years to come, the RFR begins to fall, I am sure these businesses will suffer in getting workers.

“Bye-bye Babies!”

Just a reminder about headlines.  When creating a “catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea,” include only what you see in the graph.  Of course, the article’s headline in the New York Times incorporates other ideas that are discussed in the article, but here do not include other ideas that are not displayed in the graph.

comment info:

What do you wonder?- I wonder how it's going to end for us. Honestly maybe a bit dark, but I've thought about it a few times in the past too. We have such a high population, and we're only starting to live longer and longer. We live to an age that's honestly quite unstable if that makes sense. It gets to a point where you question if living is even living when you're that old. Living just barely is honestly considerably worse than dying.

How does this relate to you and your community?-  I think it's obvious that this effects me and my community because this is the earth we live on. This is the only place we've ever known. We live here and we die here. This is our home. And it's becoming a rapidly growing place to live clearly by the population spikes. However, it's also true that the spike is intended to decline a bit after we reach 10 bil. But that also has me wondering if that many people on one floating rock can be called habitable.

Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea. 
Overpopulation graph simulation!
